comments: N/A
n/a
The majority of the discussions were done as a class since it was nice and small group but we also made use of the breakout rooms to have discussions in partner settings.
Virtual seminar, outside class readings and movies to watch

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained skills in being able to read, speak, and comprehend French and learned about public health in France and francophone countries!

I developed the knowledge of a multitude of french vocabulary pertaining to medical topics and knowledge of a very wide, diverse array of medical topics that have a social bearing on both the US and the francophone world.

I learned medical french vocabulary, as well as explored different medical and ethical issues in various francophone countries. I improved my reading/listening comprehension watching and reading materials and discussed their significance in our medical world today.

In this class, I learned about the differences between the France and US healthcare system. It was really interesting to learn about the various laws and perspectives on healthcare as it reflected much of the cultural differences in values and beliefs. In addition, I learned many new medical vocabulary words that were unfamiliar to me before having taken the course.

I learned so much in this course, primarily surrounding the medical system in France and in french-speaking countries. The material was very accessible (I am not pre-med or a STEM student) and I loved it.

definitely improved my speaking skills
practice on writing and reading as well

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class was absolutely fantastic, my favorite of the semester! It was a small seminar so we were really able to engage with our classmates in discussion about the material that covered all sorts of topics including disabilities, mental illness, malaria and epidemic diseases, and les Algues Vertes, which allowed me to become more comfortable speaking and understanding the language. Professor Tertrain is a fantastic professor who cares about all of his students!
I honestly think that the course is perfect the way it is. I loved it.
Strengths are Leo - his style of teaching, organization, personality. No weaknesses.
We were a small class so engagement was super high and everyone participated a lot each class. If people were participating less then the professor would gently encourage them to speak

strengths: engaging, encouraging environment, interesting assignments and material 
weaknesses: honestly none. I felt like the course was really well designed and executed.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having small discussions over Zoom was great, the seminar was so small we didn't need to use breakout rooms as much but I felt the class succeeded in adapting to the online format.

Zoom succeeded well in taking the place of an in-person seminar. For the technology presentation,  it was actually made things a bit easier than I imagine they would have been in person. One practice that I think could change is that more documents could be posted on canvas instead of emailed, for the sole purpose of being able to be easily accessed again.
The Zoom seminar format was the best way to encourage learning during the pandemic. No improvements could have been made.
All were amazing and the professor was very accommodating

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely!!! Professor Tertrain is an amazing professor who cares about each of his students and the class is so interesting if you have any interest in global/public health and/or French culture and language studies.

Most definitely - speaking skills are improved immensely, as well as listening and reading skills. Particularly since some of the documentaries and videos didn't have subtitles. The course is very laid back in that there is no pressure to speak and the atmosphere is very encouraging all around.
Yes, definitely. I took both of Leo's classes - Medical and Business French. Both are great courses because of him.
Yes, professor Tertrain is amazing and cares so much about his students. His thought-provoking questions incite deep conversations and discussions, making the class so entertaining.
Yes, yes, yes! One of my favourite courses at Yale and I hope to take more courses with the professor
yes! it's really great for people looking to keep up their language skills.
